title: The Flying Roll and Wickedness
shortSummary: Zechariah chapter 5 presents two vivid visions symbolizing God's judgment on sin and wickedness. The flying roll represents a curse against theft and false swearing, while the ephah with the woman inside symbolizes the pervasive nature of iniquity being removed from the land. These visions emphasize God's holiness and the certainty of divine justice.
timeline: c. 520 BC - Post-exilic period during the prophetic ministry of Zechariah

keyCharacters.name: Zechariah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who receives and records the visions, serving as God's messenger to Israel.

keyCharacters.name: The Angel
keyCharacters.description: The heavenly guide who explains the visions to Zechariah and reveals their meaning.

keyCharacters.name: The Woman in the Ephah
keyCharacters.description: A symbolic figure representing wickedness or iniquity, confined and removed from the land.

definitions.definition: A large scroll that flies through the air symbolizing the swift and certain execution of God's curse against sin.
An ancient Hebrew unit of dry measure, here used symbolically as a container for wickedness.
A heavy weight of lead used to seal the ephah, symbolizing containment and judgment.
A divine judgment or condemnation pronounced against sin and disobedience.

outline.heading: The Vision of the Flying Roll
outline.description: Zechariah sees a large flying scroll representing a curse that will sweep across the earth, targeting thieves and those who swear falsely by God's name, illustrating the certainty of divine judgment on sin.

outline.heading: The Vision of the Ephah and the Woman
outline.description: The prophet is shown an ephah containing a woman symbolizing wickedness, sealed with a heavy lead weight, signifying the containment and removal of sin from the land.

outline.heading: The Removal of Wickedness to Shinar
outline.description: Two winged women carry the ephah to the land of Shinar where a house will be built for it, symbolizing the permanent exile of iniquity away from God's people.

application: Recognize that God’s holiness demands justice; sin such as theft and falsehood cannot be tolerated and will be judged.
Confess and repent of personal sins, understanding that God’s judgment is both certain and righteous.
Trust in God’s power to remove wickedness from your life and community, seeking His cleansing and restoration.
Commit to living with integrity and truthfulness, honoring God’s name in all speech and actions.

keyVerses.text: Then said he unto me, This is the curse that goeth forth over the face of the whole earth: for every one that stealeth shall be cut off as on this side according to it; and every one that sweareth shall be cut off as on that side according to it.
keyVerses.significance: This verse clearly states the universal scope of God's judgment against theft and false swearing, emphasizing the seriousness of sin.

keyVerses.text: And he said, This is wickedness. And he cast it into the midst of the ephah; and he cast the weight of lead upon the mouth thereof.
keyVerses.significance: This verse identifies the woman as wickedness itself and shows God's sovereign act of containing and judging sin.

keyVerses.text: And he said unto me, To build it an house in the land of Shinar: and it shall be established, and set there upon her own base.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the final removal and exile of wickedness, symbolizing God's cleansing of His people and land.
